channel.title: New local problems on FixMyStreet
channel.description: The latest local problems reported by users

item.title: Hedge needs cutting back of 46 - 82 Appledore Crescent, 16th July
item.description:
The hedge at the back of the properties has grown very tall and is very oppressive. It needs cutting back.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Appledore Crescent, Longlands, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: No copyright intended but required is full trading standards investigation and PVG training review in United Kingdom for BT/EE employees and those contracted, 16th July
item.description:
Team After being misled and misold a product the person it was escalated to needs pvg retrained They seemed to follow a script and not seemed to listen to customer All they seemed interested in was ticking a box to resolve it at their side They told customer I see you are in contact that will cost you to leave When actually customer was misled and BT/EE seemed to loose data from September 2024 again give the opportunity to put it right Jan 2025 and July 2025 Instead of respect to customer and a refund of 900 that they should give They gave inaccurate picture from their side Trading standards because mySociety umbrella platform seems to indicate many Unresolved issues in your area It's City wide Unresolved Request full trading standards review of all BT/EE centres and training

Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Bollards broken, 16th July
item.description:
The bollards outside SaundersAbbot garage are broken. I suspect the garage is responsible to facilitate them driving the vans for sale over the pavement onto the road. These bollards are there for a reason to stop this. The garage are constantly driving vehicles over the pavement causing danger to pedestrians and other road users

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 180, Halfway Street, Longlands, Sidcup, London

item.title: Dangerous parking of large vehicle, 16th July
item.description:
There is a large white vehicle constantly parked on the pavement on the corner of Palewell Close and Broom Avenue. Not only is it parked illegally (no pavement parking signed on the road) but it takes up so much of the pavement that it is obstructing pedestrians. It is also blocking the view of drivers trying to leave Palewell Close, turning it into a blind bend. Yesterday there was almost a head on collision due to the driver leaving Palewell Close being unable to see oncoming traffic until they had pulled out of the road.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Palewell Close, St Paul's Cray, London
Report on FixMyStreet
